pullRequest.body:
Add `lift_unique`, `lift_unique'` to `IsFractionRing`

---

GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

nodes.body:
### PR summary [de4329db93](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19124/commits/de4329db930b11384da56d23d59d4d8a595bb6f7)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ lift_unique`
`+ lift_unique'`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Is this really useful? I mean `rw [lift_unique' hg hf1 hf2]` can be just `rw [← lift_unique hg hf1, lift_unique hg hf2]`.

> Is this really useful? I mean `rw [lift_unique' hg hf1 hf2]` can be just `rw [← lift_unique hg hf1, lift_unique hg hf2]`.

For example. if the goal is `f1.comp f2 = g1.comp g2`, you can direcly `apply lift_unique'` and then prove the conditions, but `rw` may not find the correct function (unless we prove the conditions first and pass to it).

`g` and `L` are already defined.
```suggestion
theorem lift_unique (hg : Function.Injective g) {f : K →+* L}
```

You can prove this without reference to `g`.
```suggestion
theorem lift_unique' {f1 f2 : K →+* L}
    (hf : ∀ x : A, f1 (algebraMap A K x) = f2 (algebraMap A K x)) : f1 = f2 := by
  ext z
  obtain ⟨x, y, hy, rfl⟩ := IsFractionRing.div_surjective (A := A) z
  rw [map_div₀, map_div₀, hf, hf]
```
I have not thought of that it dosesn't depend on `g`. Thanks!

I think this statement is very similar to that of [IsPurelyInseparable.injective_comp_algebraMap](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/PurelyInseparable.html#IsPurelyInseparable.injective_comp_algebraMap). Do you think it's a good idea to rephrase this as `Function.Injective fun (f : K →+* L) => f.comp (algebraMap A K)` and rename the result as `IsFractionRing.injective_comp_algebraMap`?

> I think this statement is very similar to that of [IsPurelyInseparable.injective_comp_algebraMap](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/PurelyInseparable.html#IsPurelyInseparable.injective_comp_algebraMap). Do you think it's a good idea to rephrase this as `Function.Injective fun (f : K →+* L) => f.comp (algebraMap A K)` and rename the result as `IsFractionRing.injective_comp_algebraMap`?

It's a good statement but the intuition is slightly different from that of the direct form I think? Maybe I can implement both of them?
I think it's the same as your `lift_unique'` besides that the condition is `RingHom.comp f1 (algebraMap A K) = RingHom.comp f2 (algebraMap A K)`. It's the same after `ext`.

Of course they are same, but I mean 

> I think it's the same as your `lift_unique'` besides that the condition is `RingHom.comp f1 (algebraMap A K) = RingHom.comp f2 (algebraMap A K)`. It's the same after `ext`.

Of course they are the same. I mean that in some circumstances one may only consider "two homomorphisms are equal" rather than "the derived map is injective" but in other circumstances it is opposite.

> in some circumstances one may only consider "two homomorphisms are equal" rather than "the derived map is injective"

I mean what `lift_unique'` can do can also be done by `injective_comp_algebraMap`. For example, `apply lift_unique'` can give `∀ x : A, f1 (algebraMap A K x) = f2 (algebraMap A K x)`, on the other hand, `apply injective_comp_algebraMap; ext` can also give `∀ x : A, f1 (algebraMap A K x) = f2 (algebraMap A K x)`.

I don't think putting these variables on their own lines is the preferred style. For instance, see how some of the theorems on this page are structured: https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html
emm I think you're right. Sorry.

pullRequest.title: fead: Add `lift_unique`, `lift_unique'` to `IsFractionRing`

source.title: feat: add theorems to transfer `IsGalois` between pairs of fraction rings
